Intervention.evidence: opioid-sparing (OS) group receiving PVB and ketamine (n = 41), and the control group (n = 21) treated with postoperative morphine infusion

Objective.evidence: We evaluated the efficacy of a perioperative multimodal analgesia protocol incorporating paravertebral block (PVB) and ketamine infusion in patients undergoing video-assisted thoracic surgery (VATS).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the need for rescue opioid therapy; secondary outcomes included postoperative pain scores assessed at multiple time points over 48 h using the numeric rating scale (NRS)

Number_Randomised.evidence: opioid-sparing (OS) group receiving PVB and ketamine (n = 41), and the control group (n = 21)

Result_Outcome.evidence: Rescue opioid administration was significantly lower in the OS group (19.5% vs. 47.6%, p = 0.021).

Harms.evidence: No differences in haemodynamics were reported, nor were there any ketamine/PVB-related complications.
